model.hed: Top 20 Hotels in the Pacific Northwest
model.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate the top hotels in Oregon and Washington

memberComments.comment: "A worthwhile splurge for a birthday or honeymoon. The fixed price breakfast is mythic and memorable. A cozy, well-maintained place in a beautiful setting."
"This a beautiful spot on a beautiful river."
"Perfect. Great beds, good location, close walk to Riverfront Park."
"Their customer service is great, and the rooms are very comfortable and luxurious."

This is the best hotel in the country!  From the minute you enter, you feel valued as a guest and as a person.  The cocktail get-together is funÑyou can make a postcard that the hotel will send for youÑand you get to meet other guests.  Pet-friendly doesn't begin to describe the hotel's attitude towards furry guests.
Great location, friendly service, best of Seattle's designer hotels.
One of Spokane's gems. A beautifully restored treasure and a great place to have dinner. We especially enjoyed the dinner specials at the Safari Room.
The photos just can't do the Davenport justice. The building is absolutely breathtaking and all of the details are precisely maintained. The service, food and spa are amazing!
Great property, service, and beautiful room.
Wonderful event staff and space. Best conference location in downtown Seattle.
The staff go out of their way to make our stays absolutely perfect - so much so that we go out of our way to stay here at least once a year!
Extremely congenial, helpful staff from the  valet to the front desk, bar to Trellis Restaurant. A classy hotel with comfortable rooms.
Great place right in the heart of Portland. Great restaurant and bar area. Features local wines. Within walking distance to many attractions.

Amazing staff! Wonderful award-winning restaurant with a great happy hour to boot. Love to stay here when I am in town. In the heart of downtown for easy access to shopping and cultural arts and next to the Arlene Schnitzer Concert Hall.

Very well designed property. Rooms have a great layout and flow nicely. Staff are super friendly and accommodating. Unbelievable facilities at the attached health center. It's perfect for families but we thoroughly enjoyed it as a couple just the same. Hotel was nicely separated from the facilities. Excellent selection of dining options. There should be mpre hotel properties like this one!
Really cool concept with the over the top workout center.
Well located and the staff is extremely helpful. Restaurant is very good and it's fun to relax around the courtyard firepits.
Lovely hotel with a good restaurant. While rooms were smallish, they were nicely appointed, and service was great.
Nice surprise, would definitely stay there on my next trip to Seattle. Great location, fun place!
Loved the location of this hotel in downtown Seattle. It was convenient to anything we wanted to see and do during our stay.

items.name: The Heathman Hotel, Portland
items.description: Next to the Portland Center for Performing Arts, this 1927 hotel is in the cultural district and within walking distance to many attractions, such as the Rose Garden and South Waterfront. "The service is first-class from the moment the valet opens the car door to the end of your stay." "It’s not your average rabbit hutch design of many modern places." Acanthus leaves decorate the mezzanine’s plaster columns and ceiling trim, upper-floor windows are trimmed in stone, and more than 3,000 autographed first-edition books are on display. Rooms have dark wood furniture and original artwork created by Northwestern artists. "From the choices in mattresses, to the Beefeater-attired doormen, to the unfailingly helpful staff, this hotel is one of my favorites in any city. It’s centrally located, and the restaurant/bar serves the perfect-size nosh for travelers who arrive hungry but aren’t ready for a meal." The Heathman focuses on Pacific Northwest dining with a French influence, while an adjacent marble bar offers afternoon tea.

items.name: Allison Inn & Spa
items.description: Surrounded by vineyards, orchards, and farmland, this "jewel of a resort" 45 minutes south of Portland rises from 35 hillside acres in Oregon’s Willamette Valley wine country, making it "a great base for a winery tour." The "beautifully designed and appointed" decor comes courtesy of polished woods, copper accents, artwork from local artists, and furnishings and fabrics in ocher, pumpkin, eggplant, and leaf green that reflect the surroundings. The Living Room has a stone fireplace and outdoor terrace; the indoor pool with floor-to-ceiling glass doors opens to the estate garden. "Very spacious rooms" have private terraces or balconies and custom-crafted furnishings—"we loved the in-room fireplaces." Serving up local produce from the chef’s garden, Jory also offers Oregon wines, microbrews, and handcrafted distilled spirits.

items.name: The Historic Davenport Hotel
items.description: The Historic Davenport Hotel sits on one of the most popular streets in Spokane, making it ideal for business travelers and shoppers. Rooms feature exotic decor: gold hues, animal prints, and leafy plants. The hotel has an indoor pool and hot tub, as well as 24-hour business and fitness centers. The Palm Court Grill is known for its prime rib and Crab Louis salad.

items.name: Fairmont Olympic Hotel
items.description: Transformed into a hotel in 1924, this downtown brick and terra-cotta Italian Renaissance tower "exudes beautiful old-world elegance." The "excellent location" is blocks from the Seattle Art Museum and Pike Place Market. Rooms in rose, soft yellow, and seaside blues "may not have a lot of character but are well appointed" with neoclassical writing desks, marble bathrooms, and custom wallpaper. Corner suites have parlors with antique furniture. With 17-foot Palladian windows and crystal chandeliers, The Georgian prepares French-inspired Pacific Northwest cuisine. At the oyster bar Shuckers, the "seafood is superb." "Everyone was capable and courteous."

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Seattle
items.description: This contemporary property is in an excellent location near Pike Place Market and across the street from Seattle Art Museum. A staircase leads guests to the waterfront, while interior design incorporates natural sycamore and ash woods with artisan glass and custom carpets. The hotel's restaurant, Goldfinch Tavern by critically acclaimed chef Ethan Stowell, opened summer 2015 with cutting-edge Pacific Northwest cuisine.

items.name: Heathman Hotel, Kirkland
items.description: This newcomer opened in 2007 on the eastern shore of Lake Washington. "All of the staff were wonderful and even offered me a complimentary upgrade when I had to wait a little longer than expected due to an unruly guest in front of me. Going that extra mile really left an impression—can’t wait to stay there again." Remaining consistent with Kirkland’s turn-of-the-century look, the exterior showcases arches, balconies, and brick and stucco finishes, while the interior uses stone, wood, and metal. Trellis Restaurant offers "fabulously prepared" farm-to-table cuisine with organic ingredients mostly grown on the hotel’s ten-acre farm in nearby Woodinville. Rooms are "immaculate and modern."

items.name: Hotel 1000
items.description: This relaxed yet upscale spot is in downtown Seattle, blocks from Seattle Art Museum and Pioneer Square. Rooms with panoramic views have beds with raw silk throws and velvet pillows; bathrooms come with a limestone-tile walk-in shower and a huge tub with water cascading from the ceiling. BOKA’s seasonal menu lists dishes such as Northwest fish tacos and baked mac & cheese; it's a popular spot for locals as well as out-of-town visitors.

fields.caption: Our readers love the "unique style" of this hotel, noting the "beautiful, modern rooms that feature glass-wall details and "tubs that fill from the ceiling." "Even the colors used make you feel like you are being pampered in your own private spa," says one reader, "of course, that's also available." Readers had good things to say about the hotel restaurant's food and cocktails, as well as the service, which was "personal" and "outstanding." One reader noted that the manager left mini cupcakes and an anniversary note in her suite; another who attended a business meeting at the hotel called it "very personable and convenient for shopping."
fields.title: Hotel1000, Seattle

items.name: Inn at the Market
items.description: An inn only by name, this boutique hotel, perched on a hilltop in Pike Place Market, is a chic stay "in the heart of quintessential Seattle". Minimalist rooms with bay windows offer unbeatable views of the market, the ferries cutting across Elliott Bay, and on a clear day, the Olympic mountain range. An ivy-draped inner courtyard is home to Bacco, a popular happy hour spot; nearby, Café Campagne hosts a spirited Bastille Day party every year.

fields.caption:
**


Our readers say**: "In the heart of quintessential Seattle," this brick hotel is on a hillside above Pike Place Market. The "very fun atmosphere" is created, in part, by an ivy-draped inner courtyard with shops, restaurants, and a fountain. Minimalist rooms have silk and chenille accents and bay windows with "beautiful views of the market and Elliott Bay," and Hypnos bedding. Campagne serves southern French specialties in a softly lit room of red banquettes and hand-blown glass light fixtures. The healthy bistro, Bacco, blends fresh fruit and vegetable juices. "Every detail from the greeting to checkout was exemplary."
fields.title: [Inn at the Market](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/inn-at-the-market-seattle-seattle-washington)

items.name: Pan Pacific Hotel Seattle
items.description: The hotel chain’s first new-build in the United States anchors a master-plan development in South Lake Union containing condo buildings, restaurants, and a waterfront park. Just blocks from Seattle’s retail hub and Experience Music Project, the 160-room hotel has eye-of-the–Space Needle views of the city. Inside, the modern-organic decor strikes the right balance between high design and cushy comfort, with zebrawood, vivid art, a Jerusalem limestone fireplace, and a welcoming lobby bar. Rooms come equipped with luxe niceties—Villeroy & Boch basins, a soaker tub (some with shoji), a chaise longue, and plush bedding—as well as free Wi-Fi. Seastar Restaurant and Raw Bar is a fresh addition to this food-obsessed city; in a pinch you can also grab a snack at Whole Foods, just downstairs.

items.name: Salish Lodge & Spa
items.description: "Breakfast—fresh everything—is the perfect start to a morning of misty wilderness adventure." Built in 1916 as a rest stop for travelers, this Cascade Mountains property is set above 268-foot-high Snoqualmie Falls. The setting for the TV series Twin Peaks, the mountain lodge offers rooms in blues, emeralds, and turquoises (to mirror the colors of the sky, the Snoqualmie River, and Puget Sound) with custom-built furniture and two-person whirlpool tubs. "It’s our getaway place. The sound of the falls 24/7, a real fireplace in your room, a book from their library, and a cool glass of Washington wine. Sounds like heaven, right?" A honeybee apiary on the hillside by the lodge produces honey for the spa and the Dining Room, where local artisanal cheeses are also served. At the Attic, order a Salish smoked-salmon chowder. "The staff are prompt, friendly, knowledgeable, and polite. I love this place."

items.name: Stephanie Inn
items.description: "This is the nicest ocean retreat on the West Coast." Named for the owner’s daughter and designed like a New England country inn, the property is "relaxing and mesmerizing," "an amazing place to unwind and put up your feet." It has a stacked stone fireplace in the lobby, and an oceanfront library and chart room. Staff are "the friendliest—they feel more like family than people running a business." "We loved the wine-tasting in the afternoon." At the Dining Room, which has a river rock fireplace and serves Pacific Northwest cuisine, "the dinners are excellent." Rooms in aquas and blues, or warm reds, have fireplaces and views of the ocean.

fields.title: Stephanie Inn
fields.caption:
**Overall Score: 93.0**


See full rating information for** [Stephanie Inn](/hotels/north-america/united-states/stephanie-inn-cannon-beach-cannon-beach-oregon)[](http://../../hotels/north-america/united-states/fearrington-house-country-inn-pittsboro-pittsboro-north-carolina.html)**

items.name: The Nines (Luxury Collection)
items.description: Opened in 2008, this hotel in the glazed terra-cotta Meier & Frank Building—a former flagship department store—is in "a perfect downtown location." Blending modern and traditional elements, the artwork and fashion-influenced design are a nod to its retail past. Corridors with crystal chandeliers lead to "Hollywood-glam rooms" with ivory leather headboards and mercury glass lamps. Guests "love the interior atrium" soaring seven stories above a lobby with espresso-colored hardwood floors and gold foil–like walls. With a 20-foot communal table and "second-to-none staff," the modern steak house Urban Farmer highlights local organic produce; Departure’s coastal cuisine includes sushi, dim sum, and a milk chocolate cream with ginger dessert.

items.name: Tu Tu' Tun Lodge
items.description: Have a "calm and memorable stay" at this rustic timber lodge set on the Rogue River. Rooms have Asian decor, hardwood mission-style furniture, details like steam showers and binoculars for watching wildlife, and some come with cedar hot tubs on balconies. "Staff are extraordinary." "The food—especially breakfast—is gourmet and so delicious," served family-style in the dining room, where guests are seated communally. The 2,800-square-foot, Craftsman-inspired guest lodging called Osprey Bend has three king bedrooms, a fully stocked kitchen, hand-hammered copper sinks, wide-plank myrtlewood flooring, and a wraparound cedar deck.

fields.caption:
**


 Our readers say**: Have a "calm and memorable stay" at this rustic timber lodge set on the Rogue River. Rooms have Asian decor, hardwood Mission-style furniture, details like steam showers and binoculars for watching wildlife, and some come with cedar hot tubs on balconies. "Staff are extraordinary." "The food—especially breakfast—is gourmet and so delicious," served family-style in the dining room, where guests are seated communally. New in 2011: a 2,800-square-foot, Craftsman-inspired guest lodging called Osprey Blend that has three king bedrooms, a fully stocked kitchen, hand-hammered copper sinks, wide-plank myrtlewood flooring, and a wraparound cedar deck.
fields.title: [Tun Tu' Tun Lodge](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/tu-tu-tun-lodge-gold-beach-gold-beach-oregon)
